claims_to_validate.claim_text: The current Bayzat payroll system lacks automated salary calculation based on precise working days. The platform cannot dynamically adjust salaries proportionally when employees work more or fewer than the standard 26 working days.

The daily wage calculator in payroll settings overrides the leave policy formula for unpaid leave. The system shows a greyed-out formula in leave policy that is intentionally replaced by the payroll-side configuration. This creates user confusion about which formula is actually being applied.

System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were incorrectly based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in payroll calculation discrepancies.

The system incorrectly calculates service days by using 365 days instead of 366 days for 2024, resulting in an inaccurate gratuity amount. The correct calculation should include 366 days for leap years.

End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.

System gratuity calculation shows slight differences from manual calculations, with complexity arising from service duration splits and tiered gratuity rates (21 days per year for first 5 years, 30 days per year after 5 years).

The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently handle leap year days (specifically February 29th), causing minor discrepancies in total service days and resulting gratuity amount. The system calculated 912 days, while manual calculation suggested 913 days by including the leap day.

System calculates days worked with a potential extra day (622 vs 623 days), causing slight variations in gratuity calculation. The platform uses a fixed daily wage divisor of 30 days, which differs from client's preferred calculation method of (Basic × 12 / 365).

System calculates leave salary based on a fixed policy configuration that may not align with user expectations about calendar days. User believed daily wage should be divided by 31 days, but system was dividing by 30 days, resulting in a slight salary calculation difference (2940 SAR vs expected 2988 SAR).

The system calculates leave salary and salary proration using independent daily wage configurations with different divisors (30 vs 30.42 days), causing calculation mismatches. The leave salary policy uses a 30-day divisor while salary proration uses 30.42 days, leading to different prorated amounts.

User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was actually calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

The system fails to correctly prorate salary when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing date. When an employee is offboarded (e.g., on Nov 28th) and payroll is processed earlier (e.g., on Nov 27th), the system displays the full monthly salary instead of a prorated amount. The system only correctly prorates salaries when the departure date is in the past.

When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Moving the leave request back to pending/accepted does not resolve the issue. Even after deleting the unpaid leave request entirely, the unpaid leave deduction persists in payroll deductions.

When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, the daily wage calculation becomes inconsistent between Payroll and Time Off modules. This causes incorrect salary deduction amounts that cannot be retroactively corrected.
The system displays incorrect daily rate in remarks for February, showing 31 days instead of 29 days, despite the underlying calculation being mathematically correct.

The system applies a global daily rate configuration that supersedes individual leave policy settings for unpaid leave calculations. This can result in deductions calculated using gross salary instead of basic salary, contrary to policy configurations.

The system shows the daily rate from the payroll processing month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate is from the wrong month.
Salary is based on a standard 26 working days per month, calculated using the formula: 365 (Days yearly) - 52 (Weekly off) = 313 / 12 = 26.08 working days
For unpaid leave, the daily wage calculator configured in payroll settings takes precedence over the leave policy formula. The leave policy formula is greyed out and cannot be applied.
